aeFXActions Framework

A small but versatile framework for speeding up development of JavaFX/FXML applications: use a declarative syntax for binding actions to the UI controls, for a clean separation of logic and presentation and more fun with JavaFX.

See: Description

Packages 
Package Description
com.aeonium.javafx.actions
The main package, contains the abstract base classes of the FXActions framework and the FXActionManager.
com.aeonium.javafx.actions.annotations
Standard annotations for the aeFXActions framework
com.aeonium.javafx.actions.progress
Experimental - do not use yet: Extension for progress tracking.
com.aeonium.javafx.actions.util
Helper classes for the framework, not primarily for common use.
com.aeonium.javafx.behaviour
Base classes for the behaviour part of the framework - this is merely the annotation, the default annotation handler and the base class for all custom behaviour implementations.

A small but versatile framework for speeding up development of JavaFX/FXML applications: use a declarative syntax for binding actions to the UI controls, for a clean separation of logic and presentation and more fun with JavaFX.

Goals and Principles

The aeFXActions framework adheres to the following principles:

  • A perfect separation of presentation and logic.
  • Declarative binding of actions to UI Controls. No imperative glue code anymore.
  • Reusable action logic classes that encapsulat your interaction logic. In the standard use case these classes are thoght as singletons.
  • One place to describe the common features o appearance, i.e., caption, tooltip, etc.
  • One place to enable or disable the action, regardless where and how often it is placed in the GUI.

Bootstrapping

Compared to ordinary JavaFX applications with FXML UI, there are just a few steps to get started with FXML and the aeFXActions framework.

The framework uses the controller factory callback of the FXMLLoader. So, you (merely) have to tell the FXMLLoader that loads your FXML files to use the FXActionManager as a controller factory. The followin example illustrates the application initialization with aeFXActions: 

  public void start(Stage stage) throws Exception {
    FXActionManager myActionControllerFactory = new FXActionManager();

    // Shortcut, if you have a fxml without stylesheets
    //Parent root = FXMLLoader.load(
    //        getClass().getResource("FXMLDocument.fxml"),
    //        null,
    //        null, myActionControllerFactory);

    // use this approach if the fxml uses stylesheets:
    FXMLLoader fxmlLoader = new FXMLLoader();
    fxmlLoader.setLocation(getClass().getResource("FXMLDocument.fxml"));
    fxmlLoader.setControllerFactory(myActionControllerFactory);
    Parent root = (Parent) fxmlLoader.load();

    myActionControllerFactory.initActions();

    // optional: get the action by its type and parametrize it:
    MyAction action = myActionControllerFactory.getAction(MyAction.class);
    action.setText("Erste Aktion");

    Scene scene = new Scene(root);

    stage.setScene(scene);
    stage.show();
  }
